title: CVE-2020-10938-buffer overflow/out-of-bounds write in compress.c:HuffmanDecodeImage()

profile.name: Internet Bug Bounty
profile.about: The Internet Bug Bounty rewards security research into vulnerabilities impacting Open Source Software Projects.

activities.message:
Hi @nathaniellives,

Thank you for your submission. Your report is currently being reviewed and the HackerOne triage team will get back to you once there is additional information to share.

Kind regards,
@sodacan

Hi,

In terms of proving that I am the original finder, how do you usually deal with that for items mandated to be externally reported first? I have the email chain and can establish ownership of the relevant email addresses. 

In terms of public security advisory, I will need to apply for a CVE. I usually don't because it feels ego driven but I was not aware that was a requirement.

Hi @nathaniellives,
Please read our common response below:
**If you are attempting to report a new security vulnerability in a third-party library, please first contact the project maintainers directly.**

Vulnerabilities in open source libraries should first be validated, accepted, and publicly disclosed by the project maintainers before submission to the [Internet Bug Bounty Panel](https://internetbugbounty.org/#the-panel).,
@sodacan

Hello,

Excuse me, The vulnerability was reported and patched to the vendor and acknowledged publicly in their changelog. Beyond establishing that I control the email address that reported it, I am uncertain of how I would establish identity. I am uncertain if acknowledgement in their changelog is sufficient in terms of public notice.
@sodacan Yes, I did that-- as noted, The vulnerability was reported and patched to the vendor and acknowledged publicly in their changelog.

Hello @nathaniellives and thanks for your report,

As stated by my colleague we will need some proof in order to proceed. You can request the CVE to the company that owns the vulnerable software which will save a lot of time in terms of agreeing that it was you who found a bug over the Internet and responsibly disclosed it.

Best regards,
@turtle_shell
@turtle_shell I've requested that the project maintainer request a CVE; I'm waiting on him. That said, is there a reason why a public changelog entry wouldn't suffice?

Hey @nathaniellives

In terms of identifying it was you, you can provide us with the means you used to disclose the issue to the maintainers, as well as a link to an advisory that publicly addresses the issue. As those won't always be credited, providing your means (whether it be email, username, etc) of contacting them can be used to relay to the team for additional verification.

Thank you,
@orangeband

Hi,

Okay, this was originally reported to the vendor via the email address justin@xor.systems. It was listed in the changelog as being credited to Justin Tripp (I was adopted and had two last names originally) here: https://sourceforge.net/p/graphicsmagick/code/ci/5b4dd7c6674140a115ec9424c8d19c6a458fac3e/ and finally its been assigned CVE-2020-10938
Following up on this as its been a quarter since the last activity...
Just out of curiosity, what is the hang up here? Is there something needed from me?
@sodacan Checking back as it has been another quarter. Is anything needed from me?

You're literally ghosting the researcher...

This problem also exists in ImageMagick and was never reported to them and never patched as a result, I'm going to drop it on FD in 7 days unless I have at the very least a reason as to why this is taking so long (and why on earth you'd make me get a CVE if you were just planning on ghosting me after I did)-- I will make sure to credit you as the party responsible for the unpatched/irresponsible drop.

Hi @nathaniellives,
First, let me empathize with your frustration in waiting so long for the program to show progress in the processing of your hard work for this submission. It's understandably not easy to have to wait nearly a year for a reply from the program to reply. Your extended patience is greatly appreciated and we have communicated the long wait times and the associated researcher frustrations via channels that have the most potential to provide the anticipated result of quick and easy communication and processing of submissions. It is our hope that these issues will be addressed sooner than later as there is a plan in progress to quickly get leverage on reports like yours. I can't provide a timeline as of yet but please know we are aware of the issues.

Second, to address your last comment below:
>You're literally ghosting the researcher...
This problem also exists in ImageMagick and was never reported to them and never patched as a result, I'm going to drop it on FD in 7 days unless I have at the very least a reason as to why this is taking so long (and why on earth you'd make me get a CVE if you were just planning on ghosting me after I did)-- I will make sure to credit you as the party responsible for the unpatched/irresponsible drop.

I'm sure you are well aware sending messages with ultimatums or threats to obtain an intended outcome are against the H1 code of conduct and could result in consequences. Please refrain from these types of behaviors. I would like to reiterate how much your patience on this report is appreciated and a reform is in the works. I hope all is well with you and those close to you. 
@sodacan

> First, let me empathize

That would mean so much more had I not spent a **2 year** period of haggling with IBB over bugs in the ruby interpreter only to have you come back after **2 years** and go, essentially, "heres a hundred bucks for all of the overflows, take it or leave it" (I imagine the whole reason you're reporting directly to the authors instead of acting as a middle man here is because I requested that the bugs I found be reverted as I did not accept the bounty due to it being several hundred dollars less than the minimum stated value.

> I'm sure you are well aware sending messages with ultimatums or threats to obtain an intended outcome are >against the H1 code of conduct

I was not aware of the code of conduct and will revise myself, however mind you that you're ripping people off for literally years at a time and coming back with the same empty lame responses-- let me tell my creditors that its okay i dont have the money or even an answer as to why i dont have the money but we've got a ticket in for a process improvement and I understand their frustration for lack of closure but whatever outcome I come to it will pay out 1/3 in 3 years time...

Hello @nathaniellives,

On behalf of the Internet Bug Bounty Panel, thank you for your continued patience on this report. The IBB is undergoing a review of all its in-scope projects and has decided to shut down this program indefinitely.

In an effort to reward researchers for their hard work and patience thus far, the IBB panel has elected to pay bounties to all valid reports at our minimum bounty amount.

As an act of good faith, we will also close this report as Resolved.

Thank you for helping keep the internet safe and secure!
-The Internet Bug Bounty Panel
